instruction:
List topics and concepts that meet the Learning objectives, enduring understanding and essential knowledge:
Example of what it should look like:
Moles
molar mass
avogadro’s number
mole fraction
Mass spectrum analysis
empirical formula
Data collection and analysis
Mass percent
Electron configuration ions and atoms
Periodic trends and comparisons
PES
Ions and electrons
Isotopes and values associated with them
Details:
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SPQ-1
The mole allows different units to be compared.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-1.A
Calculate quantities of a
substance or its relative
number of particles using
dimensional analysis and the
mole concept.
SPQ-1.A.1
One cannot count particles directly while
performing laboratory work. Thus, there must
be a connection between the masses of
substances reacting and the actual number of
particles undergoing chemical changes.
SPQ-1.A.2
Avogadro’s number (N = 6.022 × 1023 mol−1
A )
provides the connection between the number
of moles in a pure sample of a substance and
the number of constituent particles (or formula
units) of that substance.
SPQ-1.A.3
Expressing the mass of an individual atom
or molecule in atomic mass units (amu) is
useful because the average mass in amu of
one particle (atom or molecule) or formula
unit of a substance will always be numerically
equal to the molar mass of that substance
in grams. Thus, there is a quantitative
connection between the mass of a substance
and the number of particles that the
substance contains.
EQN: n = m/M
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SPQ-2
Chemical formulas identify substances by their unique combination of atoms.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-2.A
Explain the quantitative
relationship between the
elemental composition by
mass and the empirical
formula of a pure substance.
SPQ-2.A.1
Some pure substances are composed of
individual molecules, while others consist
of atoms or ions held together in fixed
proportions as described by a formula unit.
SPQ-2.A.2
According to the law of definite proportions,
the ratio of the masses of the constituent
elements in any pure sample of that compound
is always the same.
SPQ-2.A.3
The chemical formula that lists the lowest
whole number ratio of atoms of the elements in
a compound is the empirical formula.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SPQ-2
Chemical formulas identify substances by their unique combination of atoms.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-2.B
Explain the quantitative
relationship between the
elemental composition by
mass and the composition of
substances in a mixture.
SPQ-2.B.1
While pure substances contain molecules or
formula units of a single type, mixtures contain
molecules or formula units of two or more
types, whose relative proportions can vary.
SPQ-2.B.2
Elemental analysis can be used to determine
the relative numbers of atoms in a substance
and to determine its purity
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-1
Atoms and molecules can be identified by their electron distribution and energy.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-1.A
Represent the electron
configuration of an element
or ions of an element using
the Aufbau principle.
SAP-1.A.1
The atom is composed of negatively charged
electrons and a positively charged nucleus that
is made of protons and neutrons.
SAP-1.A.2
Coulomb’s law is used to calculate the force
between two charged particles.
EQN: Fcoulombic ∝ q1
q2
r2
SAP-1.A.3
In atoms and ions, the electrons can be thought
of as being in “shells (energy levels)” and
“subshells (sublevels),” as described by the
electron configuration. Inner electrons are called
core electrons, and outer electrons are called
valence electrons. The electron configuration is
explained by quantum mechanics, as delineated
in the Aufbau principle and exemplified in the
periodic table of the elements.
X THE ASSIGNMENT OF QUANTUM NUMBERS
TO ELECTRONS IN SUBSHELLS OF AN
ATOM WILL NOT BE ASSESSED ON THE
AP EXAM.
Rationale: Assignment of quantum numbers
to electrons in specific subshells does not
increase students’ understanding of the
structure of the atom.
SAP-1.A.4
The relative energy required to remove an
electron from different subshells of an atom or
ion or from the same subshell in different atoms
or ions (ionization energy) can be estimated
through a qualitative application of Coulomb’s
law. This energy is related to the distance from
the nucleus and the effective (shield) charge of
the nucleus. 
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-1
Atoms and molecules can be identified by their electron distribution and energy.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-1.B
Explain the relationship
between the photoelectron
spectrum of an atom or
ion and:
a. The electron configuration
of the species.
b. The interactions
between the electrons
and the nucleus.
SAP-1.B.1
The energies of the electrons in a given
shell can be measured experimentally with
photoelectron spectroscopy (PES). The
position of each peak in the PES spectrum is
related to the energy required to remove an
electron from the corresponding subshell, and
the height of each peak is (ideally) proportional
to the number of electrons in that subshell.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-2
The periodic table shows patterns in electronic structure and trends in
atomic properties.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-2.A
Explain the relationship
between trends in atomic
properties of elements and
electronic structure
and periodicity.
SAP-2.A.1
The organization of the periodic table is based
on the recurring properties of the elements and
explained by the pattern of electron configurations
and the presence of completely or partially filled
shells (and subshells) of electrons in atoms.
X WRITING THE ELECTRON CONFIGURATION
OF ELEMENTS THAT ARE EXCEPTIONS
TO THE AUFBAU PRINCIPLE WILL NOT BE
ASSESSED ON THE AP EXAM.
Rationale: The mere rote recall of the
exceptions does not match the goals of the
curriculum revision.
SAP-2.A.2
Trends in atomic properties within the
periodic table (periodicity) can be qualitatively
understood through the position of the element
in the periodic table, Coulomb’s law, the shell
model, and the concept of shielding/effective
nuclear charge. These properties include:
a. Ionization energy
b. Atomic and ionic radii
c. Electron affinity
d. Electronegativity.
SAP-2.A.3
The periodicity (in SAP-2.A.2) is useful to
predict /estimate values of properties in the
absence of data.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-2
The periodic table shows patterns in electronic structure and trends in
atomic properties.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-2.B
Explain the relationship
between trends in the
reactivity of elements
and periodicity.
SAP-2.B.1
The likelihood that two elements will form
a chemical bond is determined by the
interactions between the valence electrons
and nuclei of elements.
SAP-2.B.2
Elements in the same column of the periodic
table tend to form analogous compounds.
SAP-2.B.3
Typical charges of atoms in ionic compounds
are governed by their location on the periodic
table and the number of valence electrons.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-3
Atoms or ions bond due to interactions between them, forming molecules.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-3.A
Explain the relationship
between the type of bonding
and the properties of the
elements participating in
the bond.
SAP-3.A.1
Electronegativity values for the representative
elements increase going from left to right
across a period and decrease going down
a group. These trends can be understood
qualitatively through the electronic structure of
the atoms, the shell model, and Coulomb’s law.
SAP-3.A.2
Valence electrons shared between atoms
of similar electronegativity constitute a
nonpolar covalent bond. For example, bonds
between carbon and hydrogen are effectively
nonpolar even though carbon is slightly more
electronegative than hydrogen.
SAP-3.A.3
Valence electrons shared between atoms of
unequal electronegativity constitute a polar
covalent bond.
a. The atom with a higher electronegativity will
develop a partial negative charge relative to
the other atom in the bond.
b. In single bonds, greater differences in
electronegativity lead to greater bond dipoles.
c. All polar bonds have some ionic character,
and the difference between ionic and
covalent bonding is not distinct but rather
a continuum.
SAP-3.A.4
The difference in electronegativity is not the
only factor in determining if a bond should
be designated as ionic or covalent. Generally,
bonds between a metal and nonmetal are
ionic, and bonds between two nonmetals are
covalent. Examination of the properties of a
compound is the best way to characterize the
type of bonding.
SAP-3.A.5
In a metallic solid, the valence electrons
from the metal atoms are considered to be
delocalized and not associated with any
individual atom.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-3
Atoms or ions bond due to interactions between them, forming molecules.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-3.B
Represent the relationship
between potential energy
and distance between
atoms, based on factors that
influence the interaction
strength.
SAP-3.B.1
A graph of potential energy versus the distance
between atoms is a useful representation for
describing the interactions between atoms.
Such graphs illustrate both the equilibrium
bond length (the separation between atoms at
which the potential energy is lowest) and the
bond energy (the energy required to separate
the atoms).
SAP-3.B.2
In a covalent bond, the bond length is
influenced by both the size of the atom’s core
and the bond order (i.e., single, double, triple).
Bonds with a higher order are shorter and have
larger bond energies.
SAP-3.B.3
Coulomb’s law can be used to understand the
strength of interactions between cations
and anions.
a. Because the interaction strength is
proportional to the charge on each ion, larger
charges lead to stronger interactions.
b. Because the interaction strength increases
as the distance between the centers of the
ions (nuclei) decreases, smaller ions lead to
stronger interactions.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-3
Atoms or ions bond due to interactions between them, forming molecules.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-3.C
Represent an ionic solid with
a particulate model that is
consistent with Coulomb’s
law and the properties of the
constituent ions.
SAP-3.C.1
The cations and anions in an ionic crystal are
arranged in a systematic, periodic 3-D array
that maximizes the attractive forces among
cations and anions while minimizing the
repulsive forces.
X KNOWLEDGE OF SPECIFIC TYPES OF
CRYSTAL STRUCTURES WILL NOT BE
ASSESSED ON THE AP EXAM.
Rationale: Study of specific crystal structures is
not essential to an understanding of the big ideas.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-3
Atoms or ions bond due to interactions between them, forming molecules.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-3.D
Represent a metallic
solid and/or alloy using a
model to show essential
characteristics of the
structure and interactions
present in the substance.
SAP-3.D.1
Metallic bonding can be represented as an
array of positive metal ions surrounded by
delocalized valence electrons (i.e., a “sea
of electrons”).
SAP-3.D.2
Interstitial alloys form between atoms of
different radii, where the smaller atoms fill the
interstitial spaces between the larger atoms
(e.g., with steel in which carbon occupies the
interstices in iron).
SAP-3.D.3
Substitutional alloys form between atoms
of comparable radius, where one atom
substitutes for the other in the lattice. (In
certain brass alloys, other elements, usually
zinc, substitute for copper.)
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-4
Molecular compounds are arranged based on Lewis diagrams and Valence Shell
Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE
SAP-4.A
Represent a molecule with a
Lewis diagram.
ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-4.A.1
Lewis diagrams can be constructed according
to an established set of principles.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-4
Molecular compounds are arranged based on Lewis diagrams and Valence Shell
Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-4.B
Represent a molecule with a
Lewis diagram that accounts
for resonance between
equivalent structures or that
uses formal charge to select
between nonequivalent
structures.
SAP-4.B.1
In cases where more than one equivalent Lewis
structure can be constructed, resonance
must be included as a refinement to the Lewis
structure. In many such cases, this refinement
is needed to provide qualitatively accurate
predictions of molecular structure
and properties.
SAP-4.B.2
The octet rule and formal charge can be used
as criteria for determining which of several
possible valid Lewis diagrams provides the
best model for predicting molecular structure
and properties.
SAP-4.B.3
As with any model, there are limitations to
the use of the Lewis structure model,
particularly in cases with an odd number of
valence electrons.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-4
Molecular compounds are arranged based on Lewis diagrams and Valence Shell
Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-4.C
Based on the relationship
between Lewis diagrams,
VSEPR theory, bond orders,
and bond polarities:
a. Explain structural
properties of molecules.
b. Explain electron properties
of molecules.
SAP-4.C.1
VSEPR theory uses the Coulombic repulsion
between electrons as a basis for predicting
the arrangement of electron pairs around a
central atom.
SAP-4.C.2
Both Lewis diagrams and VSEPR theory must
be used for predicting electronic and structural
properties of many covalently bonded
molecules and polyatomic ions, including
the following:
a. Molecular geometry
b. Bond angles
c. Relative bond energies based on bond order
d. Relative bond lengths (multiple bonds,
effects of atomic radius)
e. Presence of a dipole moment
f. Hybridization of valence orbitals of
the molecule
SAP-4.C.3
The terms “hybridization” and “hybrid atomic
orbital” are used to describe the arrangement
of electrons around a central atom. When the
central atom is sp hybridized, its ideal bond
angles are 180°; for sp2 hybridized atoms the
bond angles are 120°; and for sp3 hybridized
atoms the bond angles are 109.5°.
X AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE DERIVATION
AND DEPICTION OF HYBRID ORBITALS
WILL NOT BE ASSESSED ON THE AP EXAM.
Rationale: The course includes the distinction
between sigma and pi bonding, the use of VSEPR
to explain the shapes of molecules, and the sp,
sp2
, and sp3
 nomenclature. Additional aspects
related to hybridization are both controversial and
do not substantially enhance understanding of
molecular structure.
X HYBRIDIZATION INVOLVING D ORBITALS
WILL NOT BE ASSESSED ON THE AP EXAM.
WHEN AN ATOM HAS MORE THAN FOUR
PAIRS OF ELECTRONS SURROUNDING THE
CENTRAL ATOM, STUDENTS ARE ONLY
RESPONSIBLE FOR THE SHAPE OF THE
RESULTING MOLECULE.
Rationale: Current evidence suggests that
main-group hybridization involving d orbitals
does not exist, and there is controversy about the
need to teach any hybridization. Until agreement
is reached in the chemistry community, we
will continue to include only sp, sp2
, and sp3
hybridization on the AP Exam.
SAP-4.C.4
Bond formation is associated with overlap
between atomic orbitals. In multiple bonds, such
overlap leads to the formation of both sigma
and pi bonds. The overlap is stronger in sigma
than pi bonds, which is reflected in sigma bonds
having greater bond energy than pi bonds. The
presence of a pi bond also prevents the rotation
of the bond and leads to structural isomers.
X MOLECULAR ORBITAL THEORY IS
RECOMMENDED AS A WAY TO PROVIDE
DEEPER INSIGHT INTO BONDING.
HOWEVER, THE AP EXAM WILL NEITHER
EXPLICITLY ASSESS MOLECULAR ORBITAL
DIAGRAMS, FILLING OF MOLECULAR
ORBITALS, NOR THE DISTINCTION
BETWEEN BONDING, NONBONDING, AND
ANTIBONDING ORBITALS.
Rationale: As currently covered in general
chemistry college textbooks, molecular orbital
theory is limited to homonuclear molecules in the
second period. 
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-5
Intermolecular forces can explain the physical properties of a material.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-5.A
Explain the relationship
between the chemical
structures of molecules and
the relative strength of their
intermolecular forces when:
a. The molecules are of the
same chemical species.
b. The molecules are of two
different chemical species.
SAP-5.A.1
London dispersion forces are a result of the
Coulombic interactions between temporary,
fluctuating dipoles. London dispersion forces
are often the strongest net intermolecular
force between large molecules.
a. Dispersion forces increase with increasing
contact area between molecules and with
increasing polarizability of the molecules.
b. The polarizability of a molecule increases
with an increasing number of electrons in the
molecule; and the size of the electron cloud.
It is enhanced by the presence of pi bonding.
c. The term “London dispersion forces” should
not be used synonymously with the term
“van der Waals forces.”
SAP-5.A.2
The dipole moment of a polar molecule
leads to additional interactions with other
chemical species.
a. Dipole-induced dipole interactions are
present between a polar and nonpolar
molecule. These forces are always attractive.
The strength of these forces increases with
the magnitude of the dipole of the polar
molecule and with the polarizability of the
nonpolar molecule.
b. Dipole-dipole interactions are present
between polar molecules. The interaction
strength depends on the magnitudes of
the dipoles and their relative orientation.
Interactions between polar molecules
are typically greater than those between
nonpolar molecules of comparable size
because these interactions act in addition to
London dispersion forces.
c. Ion-dipole forces of attraction are present
between ions and polar molecules.
These tend to be stronger than dipoledipole forces.
SAP-5.A.3
The relative strength and orientation
dependence of dipole-dipole and ion-dipole
forces can be understood qualitatively by
considering the sign of the partial charges
responsible for the molecular dipole moment,
and how these partial charges interact with an
ion or with an adjacent dipole.
SAP-5.A.4
Hydrogen bonding is a strong type of
intermolecular interaction that exists when
hydrogen atoms covalently bonded to the
highly electronegative atoms (N, O, and F)
are attracted to the negative end of a dipole
formed by the electronegative atom (N, O,
and F) in a different molecule, or a different part
of the same molecule.
SAP-5.A.5
In large biomolecules, noncovalent interactions
may occur between different molecules
or between different regions of the same
large biomolecule.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-5
Intermolecular forces can explain the physical properties of a material.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-5.B
Explain the relationship
among the macroscopic
properties of a substance,
the particulate-level structure
of the substance, and the
interactions between these
particles.
SAP-5.B.1
Many properties of liquids and solids are
determined by the strengths and types of
intermolecular forces present. Because
intermolecular interactions are broken when a
substance vaporizes, the vapor pressure and
boiling point are directly related to the strength
of those interactions. Melting points also tend
to correlate with interaction strength, but
because the interactions are only rearranged,
in melting, the relations can be more subtle.
SAP-5.B.2
Particulate-level representations, showing
multiple interacting chemical species, are a
useful means to communicate or understand
how intermolecular interactions help to
establish macroscopic properties.
SAP-5.B.3
Due to strong interactions between ions,
ionic solids tend to have low vapor pressures,
high melting points, and high boiling points.
They tend to be brittle due to the repulsion
of like charges caused when one layer slides
across another layer. They conduct electricity
only when the ions are mobile, as when the
ionic solid is melted or dissolved in water or
another solvent.
SAP-5.B.4
In covalent network solids, the atoms are
covalently bonded together into a threedimensional network (e.g., diamond) or layers
of two-dimensional networks (e.g., graphite).
These are only formed from nonmetals:
elemental (e.g., diamond, graphite) or binary
compounds of two nonmetals (e.g., silicon
dioxide and silicon carbide). Due to the strong
covalent interactions, covalent solids have high
melting points. Three-dimensional network
solids are also rigid and hard, because the
covalent bond angles are fixed. However,
graphite is soft because adjacent layers can
slide past each other relatively easily.
SAP-5.B.5
Molecular solids are composed of distinct,
individual units of covalently-bonded
molecules attracted to each other through
relatively weak intermolecular forces. Molecular
solids generally have a low melting point
because of the relatively weak intermolecular
forces present between the molecules. They
do not conduct electricity because their
valence electrons are tightly held within the
covalent bonds and the lone pairs of each
constituent molecule. Molecular solids are
sometimes composed of very large molecules
or polymers.
SAP-5.B.6
Metallic solids are good conductors of
electricity and heat, due to the presence of
free valence electrons. They also tend to be
malleable and ductile, due to the ease with
which the metal cores can rearrange their
structure. In an interstitial alloy, interstitial
atoms tend to make the lattice more rigid,
decreasing malleability and ductility. Alloys
typically retain a sea of mobile electrons and so
remain conducting.
SAP-5.B.7
In large biomolecules or polymers, noncovalent
interactions may occur between different
molecules or between different regions of the
same large biomolecule. The functionality and
properties of such molecules depend strongly
on the shape of the molecule, which is largely

SAP-6
Matter exists in three states: solid, liquid, and gas, and their differences are
influenced by variances in spacing and motion of the molecules.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-6.A
Represent the differences
between solid, liquid, and gas
phases using a particulatelevel model.
SAP-6.A.1
Solids can be crystalline, where the particles
are arranged in a regular three-dimensional
structure, or they can be amorphous, where
the particles do not have a regular, orderly
arrangement. In both cases, the motion of the
individual particles is limited, and the particles
do not undergo overall translation with respect
to each other. The structure of the solid is
influenced by interparticle interactions and the
ability of the particles to pack together.
SAP-6.A.2
The constituent particles in liquids are in
close contact with each other, and they
are continually moving and colliding. The
arrangement and movement of particles are
influenced by the nature and strength of the
forces (e.g., polarity, hydrogen bonding, and
temperature) between the particles.
SAP-6.A.3
The solid and liquid phases for a particular
substance typically have similar molar volume
because, in both phases, the constituent
particles are in close contact at all times.
SAP-6.A.4
In the gas phase, the particles are in constant
motion. Their frequencies of collision and the
average spacing between them are dependent
on temperature, pressure, and volume. Because
of this constant motion, and minimal effects of
forces between particles, a gas has neither a
definite volume nor a definite shape.

Gas properties are explained macroscopically—using the relationships among
pressure, volume, temperature, moles, gas constant—and molecularly by the motion
of the gas.

SAP-7.A
Explain the relationship
between the macroscopic
properties of a sample of gas
or mixture of gases using the
ideal gas law.
SAP-7.A.1
The macroscopic properties of ideal gases are
related through the ideal gas law:
EQN: PV = nRT.
SAP-7.A.2
In a sample containing a mixture of ideal gases,
the pressure exerted by each component (the
partial pressure) is independent of the other
components. Therefore, the total pressure of
the sample is the sum of the partial pressures.

where XA = moles A/total moles;

SAP-7.A.3
Graphical representations of the relationships
between P, V, T, and n are useful to describe
gas behavior.

Gas properties are explained macroscopically—using the relationships among
pressure, volume, temperature, moles, gas constant—and molecularly by the motion
of the gas.

Explain the relationship
between the motion
of particles and the
macroscopic properties of
gases with:
a. The kinetic molecular
theory (KMT).
b. A particulate model.

The kinetic molecular theory (KMT) relates
the macroscopic properties of gases to
motions of the particles in the gas. The
Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution describes the
distribution of the kinetic energies of particles
at a given temperature.
SAP-7.B.2
All the particles in a sample of matter are in
continuous, random motion. The average
kinetic energy of a particle is related to its
average velocity by the equation:
EQN: KE = ½ mv2
.
SAP-7.B.3
The Kelvin temperature of a sample of matter
is proportional to the average kinetic energy of
the particles in the sample.
SAP-7.B.4
The Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution provides
a graphical representation of the energies/
velocities of particles at a given temperature.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-7
Gas properties are explained macroscopically—using the relationships among
pressure, volume, temperature, moles, gas constant—and molecularly by the motion
of the gas.

SAP-7.C
Explain the relationship
among non-ideal behaviors

and/or volumes.
SAP-7.C.1
The ideal gas law does not explain the actual
behavior of real gases. Deviations from the
ideal gas law may result from interparticle
attractions among gas molecules, particularly
at conditions that are close to those resulting in
condensation. Deviations may also arise from
particle volumes, particularly at extremely
high pressures.

Interactions between intermolecular forces influence the solubility and separation

Calculate the number of
solute particles, volume, or
molarity of solutions.

Solutions, also sometimes called
homogeneous mixtures, can be solids, liquids,
or gases. In a solution, the macroscopic
properties do not vary throughout the sample.
In a heterogeneous mixture, the macroscopic
properties depend on location in the mixture.
SPQ-3.A.2
Solution composition can be expressed in a
variety of ways; molarity is the most common
method used in the laboratory.
EQN: M = nsolute /Lsolution

SPQ-3
Interactions between intermolecular forces influence the solubility and separation
of mixtures.

SPQ-3.B
Using particulate models for
mixtures:
a. Represent interactions
between components.
b. Represent concentrations
of components.
SPQ-3.B.1
Particulate representations of solutions
communicate the structure and properties
of solutions, by illustration of the relative
concentrations of the components in the
solution and drawings that show interactions
among the components.

Interactions between intermolecular forces influence the solubility and separation

SPQ-3.C
Explain the relationship
between the solubility of ionic
and molecular compounds
in aqueous and nonaqueous
solvents, and the
intermolecular interactions
between particles.
SPQ-3.C.1
The components of a liquid solution cannot
be separated by filtration. They can, however,
be separated using processes that take
advantage of differences in the intermolecular
interactions of the components.
a. Chromatography (paper, thin-layer, and
column) separates chemical species by
taking advantage of the differential strength
of intermolecular interactions between and
among the components of the solution
(the mobile phase) and with the surface
components of the stationary phase.
b. Distillation separates chemical species by
taking advantage of the differential strength
of intermolecular interactions between and
among the components and the effects
these interactions have on the vapor
pressures of the components in the mixture.

SPQ-3
Interactions between intermolecular forces influence the solubility and separation
of mixtures.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-3.C
Explain the relationship
between the solubility of ionic
and molecular compounds
in aqueous and nonaqueous
solvents, and the

between particles.
SPQ-3.C.2
Substances with similar intermolecular
interactions tend to be miscible or soluble in
one another.

SAP-8
Spectroscopy can determine the structure and concentration in a mixture of a
chemical species.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-8.A
Explain the relationship
between a region of the
electromagnetic spectrum
and the types of molecular
or electronic transitions
associated with that region.
SAP-8.A.1
Differences in absorption or emission of
photons in different spectral regions are
related to the different types of molecular
motion or electronic transition:
a. Microwave radiation is associated with
transitions in molecular rotational levels.
b. Infrared radiation is associated with
transitions in molecular vibrational levels.
c. Ultraviolet/visible radiation is associated with
transitions in electronic energy levels.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-8
Spectroscopy can determine the structure and concentration in a mixture of a
chemical species.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-8.B
Explain the properties of
an absorbed or emitted
photon in relationship to an
electronic transition in an
atom or molecule.
SAP-8.B.1
When a photon is absorbed (or emitted) by an
atom or molecule, the energy of the species is
increased (or decreased) by an amount equal
to the energy of the photon.
SAP-8.B.2
The wavelength of the electromagnetic wave is
related to its frequency and the speed of light
by the equation:
EQN: c = λν.
The energy of a photon is related to the
frequency of the electromagnetic wave
through Planck’s equation (E = ℎν). 
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SAP-8
Spectroscopy can determine the structure and concentration in a mixture of a
chemical species.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SAP-8.C
Explain the amount
of light absorbed by a
solution of molecules or
ions in relationship to the
concentration, path length,
and molar absorptivity.
SAP-8.C.1
The Beer-Lambert law relates the absorption of
light by a solution to three variables according
to the equation:
EQN: A = Ebc.
The molar absorptivity E describes how
intensely a sample of molecules or ions
absorbs light of a specific wavelength.
The path length b and concentration
c are proportional to the number of
absorbing species.
SAP-8.C.2
In most experiments the path length and
wavelength of light are held constant. In
such cases, the absorbance is proportional
only to the concentration of absorbing
molecules or ions.

TRA-1
A substance that changes its properties, or that changes into a different substance,
can be represented by chemical equations.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
TRA-1.A
Identify evidence of chemical
and physical changes in
matter.
TRA-1.A.1
A physical change occurs when a substance
undergoes a change in properties but not a
change in composition. Changes in the phase
of a substance (solid, liquid, gas) or formation/
separation of mixtures of substances are
common physical changes.
TRA-1.A.2
A chemical change occurs when substances
are transformed into new substances, typically
with different compositions. Production of
heat or light, formation of a gas, formation
of a precipitate, and/or color change provide
possible evidence that a chemical change
has occurred.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
TRA-1
A substance that changes its properties, or that changes into a different substance,
can be represented by chemical equations.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
TRA-1.B
Represent changes in matter
with a balanced chemical or
net ionic equation:
a. For physical changes.
b. For given information
about the identity of the
reactants and/or product.
c. For ions in a given
chemical reaction.
TRA-1.B.1
All physical and chemical processes can
be represented symbolically by balanced
equations.
TRA-1.B.2
Chemical equations represent chemical
changes. These changes are the result
of a rearrangement of atoms into new
combinations; thus, any representation of a
chemical change must contain equal numbers
of atoms of every element before and after the
change occurred. Equations thus demonstrate
that mass is conserved in chemical reactions.
TRA-1.B.3
Balanced molecular, complete ionic, and net
ionic equations are differing symbolic forms
used to represent a chemical reaction. The
form used to represent the reaction depends
on the context in which it is to be used.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
TRA-1
A substance that changes its properties, or that changes into a different substance,
can be represented by chemical equations.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
TRA-1.C
Represent a given chemical
reaction or physical
process with a consistent
particulate model.
TRA-1.C.1
Balanced chemical equations in their various
forms can be translated into symbolic
particulate representations.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
TRA-1
A substance that changes its properties, or that changes into a different substance,
can be represented by chemical equations.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
TRA-1.D
Explain the relationship
between macroscopic
characteristics and bond
interactions for:
a. Chemical processes.
b. Physical processes.
TRA-1.D.1
Processes that involve the breaking and/or
formation of chemical bonds are typically
classified as chemical processes. Processes
that involve only changes in intermolecular
interactions, such as phase changes, are
typically classified as physical processes.
TRA-1.D.2
Sometimes physical processes involve the
breaking of chemical bonds. For example,
plausible arguments could be made for
the dissolution of a salt in water, as either
a physical or chemical process, involves
breaking of ionic bonds, and the formation
of ion-dipole interactions between ions
and solvent.

When a substance changes into a new substance, or when its properties change, no
mass is lost or gained.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
SPQ-4.A
Explain changes in the
amounts of reactants and
products based on the
balanced reaction equation
for a chemical process.
SPQ-4.A.1
Because atoms must be conserved during a
chemical process, it is possible to calculate
product amounts by using known reactant
amounts, or to calculate reactant amounts
given known product amounts.
SPQ-4.A.2
Coefficients of balanced chemical
equations contain information regarding the
proportionality of the amounts of substances
involved in the reaction. These values can be
used in chemical calculations involving the
mole concept.
SPQ-4.A.3
Stoichiometric calculations can be combined
with the ideal gas law and calculations involving
molarity to quantitatively study gases
and solutions.
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
SPQ-4
When a substance changes into a new substance, or when its properties change, no
mass is lost or gained.

SPQ-4.B

SPQ-4.B.1
Titrations may be used to determine the
concentration of an analyte in solution. The
titrant has a known concentration of a species
that reacts specifically and quantitatively
with the analyte. The equivalence point of the
titration occurs when the analyte is totally
consumed by the reacting species in the
titrant. The equivalence point is often indicated
by a change in a property (such as color) that
occurs when the equivalence point is reached.
This observable event is called the endpoint of
the titration.

A substance can change into another substance through different processes, and
the change itself can be classified by the sort of processes that produced it.

TRA-2.A
Identify a reaction as acidbase, oxidation-reduction, or

TRA-2.A.1
Acid-base reactions involve transfer of one or
more protons between chemical species.
TRA-2.A.2
Oxidation-reduction reactions involve transfer
of one or more electrons between chemical
species, as indicated by changes in oxidation
numbers of the involved species. Combustion
is an important subclass of oxidation-reduction
reactions, in which a species reacts with
oxygen gas. In the case of hydrocarbons,
carbon dioxide and water are products of
complete combustion.
TRA-2.A.3
In a redox reaction, electrons are transferred
from the species that is oxidized to the species
that is reduced.

Oxidation numbers may be assigned to each of

TRA-2.A.5
Precipitation reactions frequently involve
mixing ions in aqueous solution to produce an
insoluble or sparingly soluble ionic compound.

The kinetics of a chemical reaction is defined

The rates of change of reactant and

TRA-3.A.3
The rate of a reaction is influenced by reactant

catalysts, and other environmental factors.

Experimental methods can be used to monitor

TRA-3.B.3

TRA-3.B.4

TRA-3.B.5
Comparing initial rates of a reaction is a

reaction species change

The order of a reaction can be inferred from a

If a reaction is first order with respect to a

If a reaction is second order with respect

1/2 = 0.693/k.

and orientation of

TRA-4.B.1
For an elementary reaction to successfully

collide to initiate bond-breaking and bondmaking events.

In most reactions, only a small fraction of

TRA-4.B.3
The Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution curve

TRA-4.C.1
Elementary reactions typically involve the

TRA-4.C.2
The reaction coordinate is the axis along

TRA-4.C.3

transition state.

A reaction mechanism consists of a series

in sequence. The components may include
reactants, intermediates, products, and catalysts.

The elementary steps when combined should

Knowledge of the energetics of each

ENE-1.A.1
In order for a catalyst to increase the rate of
a reaction, the addition of the catalyst must
increase the number of effective collisions and/

energy relative to the original reaction coordinate.
ENE-1.A.2

consumed in the rate-determining step of the

energy. There is often a new reaction intermediate
in which the catalyst is bound to the reactant(s).

ENE-1.A.4
Some catalysts involve covalent bonding
between the catalyst and the reactant(s). An
example is acid-base catalysis, in which a
reactant or intermediate either gains or loses
a proton. This introduces a new reaction
intermediate and new elementary reactions
involving that intermediate.
ENE-1.A.5
In surface catalysis, a reactant or intermediate
binds to, or forms a covalent bond with,
the surface. This introduces elementary
reactions involving these new bound
reaction intermediate(s).

ENE-2

ENE-2.A

observations and energy
changes associated with

6. Hereditary hemolytic anemia: etiology, mechanism of pathogenesis, changes of laboratory tests. The types of anemias: hereditary abnormalities of red cell membrane, red cell enzyme defects, haemoglobinopathies.

7. Inherited hemolytic anemia: etiology, mechanism of pathogenesis, changes of laboratory tests.

9. Anemia in infancy: etiology, mechanism of pathogenesis, changes of laboratory tests.
response:
I'll provide detailed answers for each of these questions:

6. Hereditary hemolytic anemia:

Etiology:
Hereditary hemolytic anemias are caused by genetic defects that affect red blood cells (RBCs), leading to their premature destruction. The main types include:

a) Abnormalities of red cell membrane (e.g., hereditary spherocytosis, hereditary elliptocytosis)
b) Red cell enzyme defects (e.g., G6PD deficiency, pyruvate kinase deficiency)
c) Hemoglobinopathies (e.g., sickle cell disease, thalassemias)

Mechanism of pathogenesis:
The genetic defects cause structural or functional abnormalities in RBCs, leading to:
- Increased fragility of RBCs
- Reduced lifespan of RBCs
- Premature destruction of RBCs in the spleen or liver
- Ineffective erythropoiesis in some cases

Changes in laboratory tests:
- Complete Blood Count (CBC): Decreased RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit; increased reticulocyte count
- Peripheral blood smear: Abnormal RBC morphology (e.g., spherocytes, elliptocytes, sickle cells)
- Increased serum bilirubin (unconjugated)
- Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
- Decreased serum haptoglobin
- Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) in some cases

Types of hereditary hemolytic anemias:

a) Hereditary abnormalities of red cell membrane:
1. Hereditary spherocytosis:
- Caused by defects in membrane proteins (e.g., spectrin, ankyrin)
- RBCs appear as spherocytes on blood smear
- Osmotic fragility test is positive

2. Hereditary elliptocytosis:
- Caused by defects in membrane proteins (e.g., spectrin, protein 4.1)
- RBCs appear as elliptocytes on blood smear

b) Red cell enzyme defects:
1. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency:
- X-linked recessive disorder
- Deficiency of G6PD enzyme leads to oxidative stress in RBCs
- Hemolysis triggered by oxidative stress (e.g., certain drugs, infections)

2. Pyruvate kinase deficiency:
- Autosomal recessive disorder
- Deficiency of pyruvate kinase enzyme impairs glycolysis in RBCs
- Chronic hemolysis

c) Hemoglobinopathies:
1. Sickle cell disease:
- Caused by mutation in beta-globin gene
- Abnormal hemoglobin S polymerizes under low oxygen conditions
- RBCs become sickle-shaped and prone to hemolysis

2. Thalassemias:
- Caused by defects in alpha or beta-globin chain synthesis
- Imbalanced globin chain production leads to ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis

7. Inherited hemolytic anemia:

This question is essentially the same as question 6, as hereditary hemolytic anemia and inherited hemolytic anemia refer to the same condition. Please refer to the detailed answer provided for question 6.

8. Hypoplastic and aplastic anemia:

Etiology:
Hypoplastic and aplastic anemias are caused by a decrease or absence of hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow. Causes include:

a) Idiopathic (most common)
b) Drugs and chemicals (e.g., chemotherapy, radiation, benzene)
c) Viral infections (e.g., hepatitis, HIV, EBV)
d) Autoimmune disorders
e) Inherited disorders (e.g., Fanconi anemia, dyskeratosis congenita)

Mechanism of pathogenesis:
- Destruction or damage to hematopoietic stem cells
- Immune-mediated suppression of hematopoiesis
- Defective stem cell function or survival
- Altered bone marrow microenvironment

Changes in laboratory tests:
- CBC: Pancytopenia (decreased RBCs, WBCs, and platelets)
- Peripheral blood smear: Reduced cellularity, may show macrocytosis
- Reticulocyte count: Low or absent
- Bone marrow biopsy: Hypocellular or acellular marrow
- Increased serum iron and ferritin levels
- Normal or elevated erythropoietin levels

9. Anemia in infancy:

Etiology:
Anemia in infancy can be caused by various factors, including:

a) Physiological anemia of infancy (normal occurrence at 2-3 months)
b) Iron deficiency anemia
c) Hemolytic disease of the newborn (e.g., ABO or Rh incompatibility)
d) Inherited disorders (e.g., thalassemias, sickle cell disease)
e) Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
f) Chronic diseases or infections
g) Lead poisoning

Mechanism of pathogenesis:
The mechanisms vary depending on the specific cause but may include:
- Inadequate erythropoiesis
- Increased RBC destruction
- Nutritional deficiencies
- Bone marrow suppression
- Blood loss

Changes in laboratory tests:
- CBC: Decreased RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit
- Peripheral blood smear: May show abnormal RBC morphology
- Reticulocyte count: Variable, depending on the cause
- Iron studies: May show low serum iron and ferritin in iron deficiency
- Hemoglobin electrophoresis: May reveal hemoglobinopathies
- Vitamin B12 and folate levels: May be low in deficiency states
- Direct antiglobulin test (DAT): Positive in hemolytic disease of the newborn
- Lead levels: Elevated in lead poisoning

Specific tests and their results will depend on the suspected cause of anemia in the infant.

Ink with Care: The Ultimate Guide to Tattoo Aftercare

Introduction: The Art of Preserving Your Living Canvas

Congratulations! You've just gotten inked, and now you're the proud owner of a stunning piece of body art. But hold on – your journey isn't over yet. In fact, it's just beginning. The moment you step out of that tattoo studio, you're embarking on a crucial mission: preserving your new tattoo and ensuring it heals beautifully. Tattoo aftercare isn't just about avoiding infection (though that's certainly important). It's about maintaining the vibrancy, clarity, and longevity of your ink. Think of your new tattoo as a living piece of art – one that requires tender loving care to reach its full potential. In this comprehensive guide, we'll walk you through everything you need to know about tattoo aftercare. From the crucial first few days to long-term maintenance, we've got you covered. So, let's dive in and learn how to keep your ink looking fresh, vibrant, and stunning for years to come!

The Importance of Proper Aftercare

Before we delve into the nitty-gritty of aftercare techniques, let's take a moment to understand why proper aftercare is so crucial.

Preventing Infection

First and foremost, good aftercare is essential for preventing infection. When you get a tattoo, you're essentially creating an open wound on your skin. This makes you temporarily more susceptible to bacteria and other pathogens. Proper aftercare helps keep these nasties at bay, reducing your risk of infection.

Promoting Healing

Aftercare isn't just about defense – it's also about actively promoting healing. The right care routine can help your skin recover faster, reducing discomfort and minimizing scabbing.

Preserving Color and Detail

Want your tattoo to look as vibrant and crisp in five years as it does today? Proper aftercare is key. By taking care of your tattoo during the healing process, you're setting the foundation for long-lasting color and sharp details.

Avoiding Complications

Neglecting aftercare can lead to various complications, from excessive scarring to patchy coloration. By following a proper aftercare routine, you're dramatically reducing the risk of these issues.

The Healing Process: What to Expect

Understanding the tattoo healing process is crucial for providing the right care at the right time. Let's break down what you can expect in the weeks following your tattoo session.

Days 1-3: The Fresh Tattoo Stage

Your tattoo is an open wound at this stage. It will be red, swollen, and tender to the touch. You may notice some oozing of blood and ink – this is normal. Your tattoo artist will have covered the area with a protective bandage or wrap.

Days 3-7: The Weeping Stage

As your tattoo starts to heal, it will begin to form a thin scab. The area may feel itchy and tight. You might notice some peeling or flaking skin. This is all part of the natural healing process.

Days 7-14: The Peeling Stage

The scab will continue to flake and peel. Your tattoo may look dull or cloudy during this stage – don't panic! This is normal and temporary.

Days 14-30: The Aftercare Stage

By now, most of the scabbing and peeling should be complete. Your tattoo will start to look more vibrant again, though it may still be slightly raised or sensitive.

1-3 Months: The Settling Stage

Your tattoo is now considered fully healed on the surface, though deeper layers of skin are still recovering. The tattoo should be smooth to the touch and have regained its vibrancy.

The Ultimate Tattoo Aftercare Routine

Now that we understand the healing process, let's dive into the nitty-gritty of tattoo aftercare. Here's a step-by-step guide to keeping your new ink in top condition.

The First 24 Hours

  • Keep the bandage on: Your artist will have covered your tattoo with a sterile bandage or wrap. Leave this in place for the amount of time recommended by your artist (usually 2-24 hours).
  • Hands off: Resist the urge to peek under the bandage or touch your new tattoo. Your hands carry bacteria that could lead to infection.
  • Stay dry: Avoid getting your tattoo wet during this initial period.

The First Wash

After the recommended time has passed, it's time for the first wash. This is a crucial step, so pay close attention:
  1. Wash your hands thoroughly with antibacterial soap.
  2. Gently remove the bandage. If it's stuck, you can soften it with some lukewarm water.
  3. Using lukewarm water and an unscented, antibacterial soap, gently wash the tattoo. Use your clean hands, not a washcloth or loofah.
  4. Rinse thoroughly with lukewarm water, ensuring all soap is removed.
  5. Pat the area dry with a clean, soft towel. Don't rub, as this can irritate the tattoo.
  6. Allow the tattoo to air dry completely before applying a thin layer of tattoo aftercare product recommended by your artist.

The Daily Routine (Days 2-14)

For the next two weeks, you'll need to follow a consistent care routine:
  • Wash twice daily: Clean your tattoo morning and night, following the steps outlined above.
  • Moisturize: After each wash, apply a thin layer of tattoo-specific aftercare product or unscented, hypoallergenic moisturizer.
  • Keep it dry: Avoid soaking your tattoo in water. Quick showers are okay, but baths, swimming, and saunas are off-limits for now.
  • Protect from the sun: Keep your tattoo out of direct sunlight. If you must be in the sun, cover it with loose, clean clothing.
  • Don't scratch or pick: As your tattoo heals, it will itch. Resist the urge to scratch or pick at scabs.
  • Wear loose clothing: Avoid tight clothes that might rub against your tattoo.

Weeks 3-4

By now, most of the scabbing and peeling should be complete. However, you should continue to:
  • Moisturize daily
  • Protect your tattoo from direct sunlight
  • Avoid soaking the tattoo for prolonged periods

Long-Term Care

Even after your tattoo is fully healed, ongoing care is important to maintain its appearance:
  • Sun protection: Always use a high SPF sunscreen on your tattoo when exposed to sunlight.
  • Moisturize: Keep your skin well-hydrated to maintain the vibrancy of your tattoo.
  • Touch-ups: Consider getting touch-ups every few years to keep your tattoo looking fresh.

Choosing the Right Aftercare Products

The products you use on your new tattoo can make a big difference in the healing process and the final result. Here's what you need to know about selecting the right aftercare products.

Cleansers

When it comes to cleaning your tattoo, simplicity is key. Look for:
  • Unscented, antibacterial soap
  • Fragrance-free, hypoallergenic cleansers
  • Products specifically designed for tattoo aftercare
Avoid:
  • Scented soaps
  • Harsh cleansers or exfoliants
  • Products containing alcohol

Moisturizers

Keeping your tattoo moisturized is crucial for healing and long-term appearance. Look for:
  • Unscented, hypoallergenic moisturizers
  • Tattoo-specific aftercare balms or lotions
  • Products with natural, soothing ingredients like coconut oil or shea butter
Avoid:
  • Scented lotions
  • Products containing petroleum jelly (in the early stages of healing)
  • Alcohol-based products

Sun Protection

Once your tattoo is healed, sun protection becomes crucial. Look for:
  • Broad-spectrum sunscreen with high SPF (30 or above)
  • Tattoo-specific sunscreens
  • Water-resistant formulas for extended outdoor activities

Common Aftercare Mistakes to Avoid

Even with the best intentions, it's easy to make mistakes during the aftercare process. Here are some common pitfalls to avoid:

Over-moisturizing

While keeping your tattoo moisturized is important, too much of a good thing can be harmful. Over-moisturizing can clog pores and trap bacteria, potentially leading to infection. Always apply a thin layer of moisturizer, just enough to keep the skin from feeling dry or tight.

Picking Scabs

As your tattoo heals, it will form scabs. It's crucial to resist the urge to pick at these scabs. Doing so can pull out ink, leading to patchy coloration or scarring. Let the scabs fall off naturally.

Soaking the Tattoo

During the healing process, prolonged exposure to water can be detrimental. Avoid swimming, taking baths, or spending too much time in the shower. When you do shower, try to keep the tattooed area out of the direct stream of water.

Exposing the Tattoo to Sunlight

UV rays can fade your tattoo and irritate healing skin. Keep your new tattoo out of direct sunlight during the healing process. Once healed, always use a high SPF sunscreen on tattooed areas when in the sun.

Using the Wrong Products

Scented lotions, harsh soaps, and alcohol-based products can irritate your healing tattoo. Stick to gentle, unscented products specifically designed for tattoo aftercare.

Wearing Tight Clothing

Tight clothes can rub against your new tattoo, causing irritation and potentially affecting the healing process. Opt for loose, breathable clothing while your tattoo heals.

Ignoring Signs of Infection

While some redness and swelling is normal in the first few days, prolonged or worsening symptoms could indicate an infection. Don't ignore signs like excessive redness, swelling, warmth, or pus. If you're concerned, consult your tattoo artist or a healthcare professional.

When to Seek Professional Help

While most tattoos heal without complications, it's important to know when to seek help. Contact your tattoo artist or a healthcare professional if you notice any of the following:
  • Excessive redness, swelling, or warmth around the tattoo
  • Pus or foul-smelling discharge
  • Fever or chills
  • Tattoo becomes painful to touch after the initial healing period
  • Rash or bumps around the tattoo
  • Excessive scabbing or bleeding
Remember, it's always better to err on the side of caution when it comes to your health and your art.

Long-Term Tattoo Care

Congratulations! You've made it through the initial healing process. But the care for your tattoo doesn't stop here. To keep your ink looking fresh and vibrant for years to come, consider these long-term care tips:

Sun Protection is Key

UV rays are the number one enemy of tattoo longevity. They can fade and blur your tattoo over time. Always apply a high SPF sunscreen to your tattoos when they'll be exposed to sunlight. For extended sun exposure, consider covering your tattoo with clothing.

Stay Hydrated – Inside and Out

Well-hydrated skin showcases tattoos better. Drink plenty of water and keep your skin moisturized. Use a good quality, unscented lotion daily to keep your tattooed skin supple and healthy.

Maintain a Healthy Lifestyle

Your overall health affects your skin, which in turn affects your tattoos. Eat a balanced diet, exercise regularly, and avoid smoking to keep your skin (and tattoos) in top condition.

Consider Touch-Ups

Even with the best care, tattoos can fade over time. Many artists offer touch-up services to refresh your ink. Consider getting touch-ups every few years to maintain the vibrancy and clarity of your tattoo.

Be Mindful of Weight Fluctuations

Significant weight gain or loss can distort your tattoo. While this isn't always avoidable, being aware of this can help you make informed decisions about tattoo placement and design.

Tattoo Aftercare for Different Body Parts

While the general principles of tattoo aftercare remain the same, different body parts may require slight adjustments to your care routine:

Hand and Foot Tattoos

These areas are prone to more movement and exposure, which can affect healing. Be extra vigilant about keeping these tattoos clean and moisturized. You may need to reapply moisturizer more frequently throughout the day.

Joint Tattoos (Elbows, Knees)

Tattoos on joints can be prone to cracking and slower healing due to constant movement. Be patient with the healing process and consider using a more occlusive moisturizer to prevent excessive dryness.

Rib and Stomach Tattoos

These areas can be sensitive and prone to rubbing against clothing. Opt for loose, breathable clothing during the healing process. You may find that healing takes a bit longer in these areas.

Scalp Tattoos

If you have a scalp tattoo, you'll need to be careful when washing your hair. Use a mild shampoo and avoid scrubbing the tattooed area directly. You may need to adjust your hairstyling routine during the healing process.

Tattoo Aftercare Myths Debunked

There's a lot of conflicting information out there about tattoo aftercare. Let's clear up some common myths:

Myth: You should use petroleum jelly on your new tattoo

Reality: While petroleum jelly can be useful for other types of wounds, it's not ideal for fresh tattoos. It can clog pores and trap bacteria, potentially leading to infection. Stick to tattoo-specific aftercare products or unscented, hypoallergenic moisturizers.

Myth: The more you moisturize, the better

Reality: Over-moisturizing can be just as harmful as under-moisturizing. It can lead to a condition called "tattoo bubbling" where excess moisture gets trapped under the skin. Always apply a thin layer of moisturizer, just enough to keep the skin from feeling dry.

Myth: You should let your tattoo "dry out" to heal

Reality: While you don't want your tattoo to be overly moist, letting it dry out completely can lead to excessive scabbing and potentially affect the final appearance of your tattoo. A balance of clean and moisturized is key.

instruction: A particular floor of a newly built dorm for undergraduate students has n rooms, and each room is equipped with a simple digital lock on the door. Tenants can set a passcode of 2 digits from 00 to 99 and the n tenants set the passcodes for their own doors independently. Find the value of n if it is known that the probability for the n passcodes to be all different is 0.75. Show your working.
response:
Let's approach this step-by-step:

1) First, we need to understand what the question is asking. We're looking for the number of rooms (n) where the probability of all passcodes being different is 0.75.

2) This is a problem of permutations. There are 100 possible passcodes (00 to 99), and we're selecting n of them.

3) The probability of all passcodes being different is the number of ways to select n different passcodes divided by the total number of ways to select n passcodes (including repetitions).

4) The number of ways to select n different passcodes from 100 options is P(100,n) = 100 * 99 * 98 * ... * (100-n+1)

5) The total number of ways to select n passcodes, allowing repetitions, is 100^n

6) So, our probability equation is:

   P(100,n) / 100^n = 0.75

7) We can write this as:

   (100 * 99 * 98 * ... * (100-n+1)) / 100^n = 0.75

8) This can be simplified to:

   0.99 * 0.98 * ... * (1 - (n-1)/100) = 0.75

9) Now, we need to find n by trial and error:

   For n = 5: 0.99 * 0.98 * 0.97 * 0.96 * 0.95 ≈ 0.8587 (too high)
   For n = 6: 0.99 * 0.98 * 0.97 * 0.96 * 0.95 * 0.94 ≈ 0.8071 (too high)
   For n = 7: 0.99 * 0.98 * 0.97 * 0.96 * 0.95 * 0.94 * 0.93 ≈ 0.7506 (very close)
   For n = 8: 0.99 * 0.98 * 0.97 * 0.96 * 0.95 * 0.94 * 0.93 * 0.92 ≈ 0.6906 (too low)

10) We find that n = 7 gives us the closest value to 0.75.

Therefore, the number of rooms (n) is 7.

instruction: in 2000-2500 words what were the accomplishments of the "Golden Age" of Islam and discuss their influence of the revival of science and learning in Western Europe?
response:
The "Golden Age" of Islam, spanning roughly from the 8th to the 14th centuries CE, was a period of remarkable scientific, cultural, and intellectual achievements that had a profound impact on the development of knowledge and learning, not only in the Islamic world but also in Western Europe. This era of Islamic civilization saw advancements in various fields, including mathematics, astronomy, medicine, philosophy, and literature. The accomplishments of this period and their influence on the revival of science and learning in Western Europe are significant and far-reaching.

Accomplishments of the Islamic Golden Age:

1. Mathematics:

One of the most notable contributions of the Islamic Golden Age was in the field of mathematics. Muslim scholars made significant advancements in algebra, geometry, and trigonometry. The term "algebra" itself comes from the Arabic word "al-jabr," which appears in the title of a mathematical treatise by the Persian mathematician Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi. Al-Khwarizmi's work laid the foundation for modern algebra and introduced the concept of algorithms, which is crucial in modern computer science.

Other notable mathematicians of this period include Abu al-Wafa, who made important contributions to trigonometry, and Omar Khayyam, who worked on cubic equations and made advancements in geometry. The development of the decimal system and the introduction of zero as a placeholder in mathematical notation are also attributed to Muslim mathematicians of this era.

2. Astronomy:

Islamic astronomers made significant contributions to the field, building upon and improving the work of ancient Greek astronomers. They developed more accurate astronomical instruments, such as the astrolabe, which was used for navigation and timekeeping. Notable astronomers of this period include Al-Battani, who calculated the length of the solar year with remarkable accuracy, and Ibn al-Shatir, whose models for planetary motion influenced later European astronomers, including Copernicus.

The establishment of astronomical observatories, such as the famous observatory in Baghdad during the reign of Caliph Al-Ma'mun, facilitated detailed observations and calculations. These observatories produced star catalogs and improved astronomical tables, which were later used by European astronomers.

3. Medicine:

Islamic medicine made significant strides during the Golden Age, with scholars building upon the works of ancient Greek physicians like Hippocrates and Galen. The Persian physician Al-Razi (Rhazes) wrote extensive medical encyclopedias and was one of the first to differentiate between smallpox and measles. Ibn Sina (Avicenna) authored "The Canon of Medicine," a comprehensive medical text that remained a standard reference in European medical schools for centuries.

Other notable achievements in medicine include the development of hospitals, the introduction of clinical trials, and advancements in surgical techniques. Muslim physicians also made important contributions to pharmacology, identifying and cataloging numerous medicinal herbs and compounds.

4. Chemistry and Alchemy:

The field of chemistry saw significant advancements during the Islamic Golden Age. Jabir ibn Hayyan (Geber) is often considered the father of chemistry, having developed many basic chemical processes such as crystallization, distillation, and sublimation. His works on alchemy laid the foundation for the development of modern chemistry.

Al-Razi made important contributions to the classification of substances and the development of laboratory equipment. The pursuit of alchemy, while often focused on the transmutation of base metals into gold, led to the discovery of many chemical processes and substances that would later prove valuable in various industries.

5. Philosophy:

Islamic philosophers made significant contributions to the field, integrating Greek philosophical traditions with Islamic theology. Notable philosophers of this era include Al-Kindi, Al-Farabi, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), and Ibn Rushd (Averroes). These thinkers engaged with and commented on the works of ancient Greek philosophers like Aristotle and Plato, preserving and expanding upon their ideas.

Islamic philosophy addressed a wide range of topics, including metaphysics, ethics, logic, and political theory. The works of these philosophers would later have a significant influence on European scholasticism and the development of Western philosophical thought.

6. Literature and Poetry:

The Islamic Golden Age saw a flourishing of literature and poetry in various languages, including Arabic, Persian, and Turkish. The development of prose and poetry reached new heights, with works like "The Thousand and One Nights" (Arabian Nights) gaining widespread popularity. Persian poets like Rumi, Hafez, and Omar Khayyam produced works that continue to be celebrated worldwide.

The development of literary forms such as the ghazal and the rubai had a lasting impact on both Eastern and Western literature. The rich tradition of storytelling and poetry from this period would later influence European literature during the Renaissance and beyond.

7. Architecture and Art:

Islamic architecture flourished during this period, with the construction of magnificent mosques, palaces, and other buildings. The development of distinctive architectural features such as the pointed arch, the dome, and intricate geometric patterns had a lasting impact on architectural styles worldwide.

Islamic art, including calligraphy, miniature painting, and decorative arts, reached new heights of sophistication and beauty. The emphasis on geometric patterns and abstract designs in Islamic art would later influence European artistic traditions.

8. Geography and Cartography:

Muslim geographers and cartographers made significant contributions to the understanding of world geography. Scholars like Al-Idrisi produced detailed world maps and geographical treatises that were more accurate than their European counterparts at the time. The development of navigational tools and techniques also advanced during this period, facilitating trade and exploration.

Influence on the Revival of Science and Learning in Western Europe:

The accomplishments of the Islamic Golden Age had a profound impact on the revival of science and learning in Western Europe, particularly during the Renaissance period. This influence was transmitted through various channels:

1. Translation Movement:

One of the most significant ways in which Islamic knowledge reached Europe was through the translation of Arabic texts into Latin. This translation movement began in earnest in the 12th century, with centers of translation established in places like Toledo, Spain. Works on mathematics, astronomy, medicine, and philosophy were translated, making the knowledge accumulated during the Islamic Golden Age accessible to European scholars.

2. Scientific and Mathematical Advancements:

The mathematical and scientific works translated from Arabic had a significant impact on European scholarship. The introduction of algebra, advanced trigonometry, and the decimal system revolutionized European mathematics. Astronomical works, including improved star catalogs and more accurate planetary models, influenced European astronomers and contributed to the eventual development of the heliocentric model by Copernicus.

3. Medical Knowledge:

The medical texts translated from Arabic, particularly the works of Ibn Sina (Avicenna) and Al-Razi (Rhazes), became standard textbooks in European medical schools. These works introduced more advanced medical knowledge and practices, improving European understanding of anatomy, pharmacology, and disease treatment.

4. Philosophical Discourse:

The works of Islamic philosophers, particularly those of Ibn Rushd (Averroes) and Ibn Sina (Avicenna), had a significant impact on European scholasticism. Their commentaries on Aristotle and their original philosophical works stimulated philosophical discourse in Europe and contributed to the development of medieval and Renaissance philosophy.

5. Scientific Method:

The emphasis on empirical observation and experimentation in Islamic science influenced the development of the scientific method in Europe. Scholars like Roger Bacon, who was familiar with the works of Islamic scientists, advocated for a more empirical approach to scientific inquiry.

6. Technological Innovations:

Various technological innovations developed or refined during the Islamic Golden Age, such as the astrolabe, advanced water clocks, and improved navigational techniques, were adopted and further developed in Europe.

7. Cultural Exchange:

The Crusades, while primarily military endeavors, also facilitated cultural exchange between the Islamic world and Europe. European scholars who traveled to the Middle East came into contact with Islamic learning and brought back knowledge and texts to Europe.

8. Centers of Learning:

The model of the Islamic madrasa (school) influenced the development of universities in Europe. The emphasis on rational inquiry and the integration of various disciplines in Islamic centers of learning provided a model for European educational institutions.

9. Renaissance Humanism:

The rediscovery of classical texts preserved and commented upon by Islamic scholars contributed to the development of Renaissance humanism. The works of ancient Greek philosophers and scientists, often transmitted through Arabic translations and commentaries, played a crucial role in shaping Renaissance thought.

10. Artistic Influence:

Islamic art and architecture had a notable influence on European artistic traditions, particularly in areas with significant Muslim presence or contact, such as Spain and Sicily. The use of geometric patterns, calligraphy, and certain architectural elements can be seen in various European artistic and architectural styles.

Conclusion:

The accomplishments of the Islamic Golden Age were vast and varied, spanning numerous fields of knowledge and cultural expression. The advancements made during this period in mathematics, astronomy, medicine, philosophy, literature, and the arts represent a significant chapter in human intellectual history. The influence of these accomplishments on the revival of science and learning in Western Europe was profound and multifaceted.

Through the translation of Arabic texts, the transmission of scientific and mathematical knowledge, the influence on philosophical discourse, and the exchange of technological innovations, the Islamic Golden Age played a crucial role in stimulating intellectual growth and scientific advancement in Europe. This transfer of knowledge and ideas contributed significantly to the Renaissance and the eventual Scientific Revolution in Europe.

The legacy of the Islamic Golden Age serves as a testament to the power of cross-cultural exchange and the cumulative nature of human knowledge. It highlights the interconnectedness of human civilization and the importance of preserving and building upon the intellectual achievements of different cultures and eras. The story of the Islamic Golden Age and its influence on Western Europe demonstrates that progress in science, philosophy, and the arts often occurs through the synthesis and development of ideas across cultural boundaries.
